newsitem.title: PERU: Hoping against hope near Peruvian crash site.
newsitem.headline: Hoping against hope near Peruvian crash site.

text.p: Holding his small niece in his arms, Tito Viali stared out at the fog-shrouded Pacific where the Aeroperu Boeing 757-200 carrying his wife crashed on Wednesday into the sea soon after taking off from Lima.
"There is still hope," he said, sobbing quietly. "There is still hope."
Viali had arrived before dawn at a barren strip of highway on the coast, along with several other relatives of the 70 passengers and crew on the Peruvian airline's flight 603 to Santiago, Chile.
While Viali expressed hope, officials in Lima said all aboard had been killed.

Rescue officials and relatives had arrived on the scene -- an eerie 500-yard (500-meter) stretch of highway cutting through the sand dunes along the coast -- soon after news broke that the aircraft had gone down.
Also on hand was a van from a national chain of undertakers, A. Merino. The vehicle's driver said he was there to transport bodies to the nearest village, a job that was becoming familiar to him.

"We have another horrible tragedy on our hands. This is becoming a habit for me," he said, explaining he had been at the site of the crash of another Peruvian aircraft in the city of Arequipa seven months ago. That accident killed 123 people on a flight operated by the Faucett airline.
As the fog lifted after dawn, street hawkers joined the silent, sombre crowd, selling soft drinks and biscuits.
Dotted along the brown dunes, about 150 fire and police officials stared blankly through the drizzle at the waves.
As traffic along the coastal highway picked up during the morning, buses stopped occasionally to let their passengers out and gaze out to sea.
They saw nothing of the crash remains. But rescue aircraft spotted pieces of the fuselage and hopes for survivors dwindled until the airline announced no one had survived.

Meanwhile, at Lima's international airport, relatives gathered for confirmation of the news, while in Santiago, dozens of family members waited in stunned silence as the word "canceled" flickered onto the screen for flight number 603.
